text: hey everybody thomas joseph here and for
today's kitchen conundrum I am tackling
the soggy waffle now I'm sure you've
encountered this some Sunday morning
where you have these soggy limp waffles
but today I'm going to show you a recipe
that will yield a perfect crisp on the
outside but fluffy on the inside waffle
that you will be making every single
weekend now to start this off I'm going
to make my own buttermilk so I have
one-and-a-half cups of whole milk and to
that I'm going to add two tablespoons of
distilled vinegar could certainly use
one and a half cups of buttermilk but
it's also nice to learn how to make it
yourself so just give this a quick stir
and this should sit for about five
minutes while that sits I have two
extra-large egg yolks in the bottom of
the bowl here if you have only large
eggs on hand you can use three egg yolks
and to this I'm going to add 3/4 of a
cup of sour cream now sour cream and
buttermilk they're very important here
because they're acidified and that
acidity is going to help in leavening
the waffle and making it nice and fluffy
when we add our baking soda and try to
make sure that your your ingredients
here are at room temperature because if
you have cold ingredients it's going to
bring the temperature of the waffle iron
down too far and you're not going to end
up with a perfectly crisp and risen
waffle so I'm going to mix together my
yolks and my sour cream here and I'm
going to add a cup of all-purpose flour
I'm gonna add 2 tablespoons of coarsely
ground cornmeal now this gives you a
wonderful crunchy texture a teaspoon of
baking soda here I'm gonna mix this
together and now I'm going to add my
homemade buttermilk and you can see
after a few minutes it gets nice and
chunky and it's perfect and ready to go
so I'm going to add this in going to
switch to a whisk a little easier to
incorporate the batter now a tip when
making waffles when making pancakes is
not to over
the batter if there are small lumps in
your batter that's perfectly okay
because they will dissipate in the
cooking process and now I'm going to add
five tablespoons of salted butter that
I've melted and cooled you could
certainly use unsalted butter and just
give it a good pinch of coarse salt and
you'll be just fine
so mix this butter in nice and
thoroughly and now for the last step and
the last lebanese agent i'm going to
whip three extra-large egg whites to
stiff peaks
it really only takes a few minutes and
these are nice and stiff perfect
- now fold into our mixture so I'm going
to take half of the whipped egg whites
and stir them gently and what this does
is it lightens the batter so it makes it
easier to fold in the rest of the egg
whites I'm going to fold in the rest of
my whipped egg whites and at this point
you really don't want to over mix the
batter because little pockets of egg
white will really help to leaven the
waffle now I have a waffle iron heating
here high heat and spray with some
nonstick cooking spray and now I'm going
to ladle in my batter about 3/4 of the
way close the waffle iron I'm gonna
rotate this just because this is the
style of the waffle iron I have and now
this is going to cook for 6 minutes now
you don't want to peek at the waffle
because this is kind of similar to a
souffle all of those egg whites are
expanding with the heat so if you
disrupt the heat it's going to collapse
a good way to gauge whether your waffle
is done or not is the steam if there's
still a lot of steam billowing out of
your waffle iron that means that it's
not ready yet so you can use that as a
gauge it's been about 6 minutes our
waffles look nice and golden-brown I
like to use a little wooden skewer to
help lift the waffle out and now a
little trick to keep the waffle nice and
crisp toss the waffle in between your
hands it lets the steam escape you could
also use a wire rack to help with that
because it has air flow underneath so
the steam is escaping and it's not
creating a sogginess
on the bottom layer of the waffle
so I'm going to use a pair of scissors
here and you can hear how crisp these
waffles are just by cutting them serve
them up while they're warm and there you
have it I'm gonna forgo the butter today
but a little bit of maple syrup is one
of my favorite things whenever I'm
having waffles if you like fruit maybe
some berries an easy recipe for crisp
yet fluffy and delicious waffles this
will be a part of your weekend
repertoire I am sure of it if you have
any kitchen conundrums that you need
solved write in the comments section
below or reach out to us using the
hashtag kitchen conundrums and we will
solve whatever kitchen problems you may
have
you
